__data__.text: The region of central southern Turkey and northwestern Syria is influenced by the interaction of the African, Arabian, and Anatolian tectonic plates. The Dead Sea Transform (DST) and the East Anatolian Fault (EAF) are major left-lateral strike-slip fault zones in this area, representing the boundary between the African and Arabian plates and the boundary between the African and Anatolian plates, respectively. These faults meet at the Marash Triple Junction, with the EAF continuing westward and linking to the Cyprus arc via the Latakia Ridge. The EAF is divided into several segments, with varying slip rates and a history of producing significant earthquakes. The northern strand of the EAF also includes several segments, including the Sürgü-Çardak Fault. The DST is divided into several segments in Turkey and Syria, and has a history of producing large earthquakes. In February 2023, a sequence of two major earthquakes occurred in this region, with magnitudes of Mw 7.8 and Mw 7.7, respectively. These earthquakes triggered numerous aftershocks and caused significant damage and loss of life.

The two major earthquakes in central southern Turkey and northwestern Syria in February 2023 were the largest in the region in over 2,000 years, triggering over 30,000 aftershocks by May 2023. The first earthquake, with a magnitude of Mw 7.8, produced aftershocks along ~350 km of the East Anatolian Fault (EAF), while the second earthquake, with a magnitude of Mw 7.7, triggered its own aftershock sequence, including two mb 6.0 aftershocks. The USGS source model for the Mw 7.8 earthquake used three fault segments with varying lengths, widths, strikes, and dips, while the USGS source model for the Mw 7.7 earthquake had three large fault segments with individual lengths, widths, strikes, and dips. The rupture of the first earthquake occurred along the Narlı Fault, the northernmost section of the Dead Sea Transform, and transitioned to supershear velocity before reaching the EAF. The rupture continued northeast onto the Ekernek segment and to the southwest onto the Amanos segment. The second earthquake initiated on a separate fault known as the Çardak–Sürgü Fault Zone and propagated bilaterally along the Çardak segment, continuing eastwards onto the Sürgü segment before continuing eastwards to Malatya along the northeast–southwest trending Doğanşehir Fault Zone. The total rupture length was estimated at 160 km. The extent of surface ruptures associated with the M7.8 and M7.7 earthquakes have been mapped using satellite imagery and ground observations, revealing two separate zones of surface rupture.

The second major earthquake in February 2023, with a magnitude of Mw 7.7, occurred on a separate fault known as the Çardak–Sürgü Fault Zone and propagated bilaterally along the Çardak and Sürgü segments. The rupture lasted about 35 seconds and was estimated to be 160 km (99 mi) long. The westward-propagating rupture occurred at supershear velocity, while the eastward-propagating rupture occurred at subshear velocity. Large surface offsets of 6-8 m (20-26 ft) were observed along the Sürgü-Çardak Fault. Ground acceleration values in some areas near the fault rupture exceeded 1 g, causing significant damage in the affected areas. Liquefaction and lateral spreading were identified in the Amik Valley, Orontes River plain, and Lake Gölbaşı, leading to extensive damage in İskenderun. A tsunami was recorded in the Mediterranean Sea, with small waves recorded along the southern Turkish coast. The earthquakes resulted in over 50,000 deaths, 297 missing persons, and 107,204 injured across 11 provinces in Turkey, affecting at least 15.73 million people and 4 million buildings. Over 2 million residents were evacuated, and at least 61,722 buildings had to be demolished.

The earthquakes caused significant damage to Turkey's agriculture production and infrastructure. The United Nations reported that crops, livestock, fisheries, aquaculture, and rural infrastructure were heavily affected. At least 516 university buildings were damaged, with 106 being heavily damaged. The Turkish government's damage inspections revealed that 164,000 buildings were either destroyed or severely damaged, and 150,000 commercial infrastructures were at least moderately damaged. The International Organization for Migration estimated that over 2.7 million people were left homeless. In Adana, at least 59 buildings and 1,274 apartments were destroyed or required demolition. In Malatya, 300 buildings were razed, and 60% of the city's buildings were damaged. Many historical sites, including Gaziantep Castle, Şirvani Mosque, and Liberation Mosque, were severely damaged in Gaziantep. In Hatay Province, 13,517 buildings collapsed, 8,162 required demolition, and 67,346 were heavily damaged. Several districts, including Antakya, Kırıkhan, and İskenderun, were the most affected. In İskenderun, a large fire at the port forced its closure and injured over 12,000 people. In Erzin District, 31 buildings collapsed, and 897 were heavily damaged or had to be demolished. In Samandağ, 670 buildings collapsed, and 7,850 people died. At least 1,046 buildings collapsed, and 3,452 others were severely damaged or had to be demolished in Hassa District. In Altınözü, 838 buildings were destroyed, and 3,892 others were badly damaged. There were 213 collapsed buildings and 1,453 others had been severely damaged or had to be demolished in Yayladağı. At least 139 buildings collapsed, 755 others were badly damaged, and 87 others had to be demolished in Belen. In Dörtyol, 115 buildings were destroyed, and 2,030 others had to be demolished or were severely damaged. Mass

The earthquakes caused extensive damage to buildings and infrastructure in several provinces of Turkey and Syria, resulting in the death of thousands of people, including Yakup Taş, a member of the Turkish parliament, and various other Turkish and Syrian civilians. In Turkey, over 20,000 buildings and 56,600 apartments were destroyed in Adıyaman Province, and many historical sites were severely damaged. In total, 164,000 buildings were destroyed or severely damaged, and 150,000 commercial infrastructures were at least moderately damaged. In Syria, at least 8,476 people died, and over 14,500 were injured. An estimated 5.37 million people across Syria may have been made homeless, and at least 453 schools were damaged. Hundreds were killed in several towns, including Jindires and Atarib, and various archaeological sites in Tartus Governorate were damaged. The earthquake also struck when rebel-held areas in Syria were preparing for a blizzard and experiencing a cholera outbreak.

The earthquakes in Turkey and Syria resulted in extensive damage to buildings and infrastructure, causing the death of thousands of people, including a Turkish parliament member, various civilians, and foreigners from several countries. Over 164,000 buildings were destroyed or severely damaged in Turkey, and at least 150,000 commercial infrastructures were at least moderately damaged. In Syria, over 8,476 people died, and at least 14,500 were injured, with an estimated 5.37 million people potentially homeless. Hundreds were killed in various towns, including Jindires and Atarib, and various archaeological sites were damaged. The earthquake struck when rebel-held areas in Syria were preparing for a blizzard and experiencing a cholera outbreak. Many buildings in both countries had already been damaged by the civil war. In Aleppo, dozens of buildings collapsed, and at least 444 people died, including 163 children. About 20,000 homes were affected, leaving 70,000 homeless. In Rajo, 20 prisoners, believed to be ISIS members, escaped a cracked prison facility. In Damascus, many people fled their homes onto the streets, and various historical sites suffered damage. The USGS PAGER service estimated a 35% probability of economic losses between US$10 billion and US$100 billion, and a 36% probability of deaths between 10,000 and 100,000. The Turkish lira and stock markets experienced fluctuations, and the total cost of earthquake damage in Turkey was estimated at $84.1 billion US dollars. The Turkish government released a preliminary report estimating the total damage cost at $103.6 billion.

The earthquakes in Turkey and Syria resulted in extensive damage and loss of life, with the death toll expected to "more than double" the initial 28,000 reported. Up to 26 million people may have been affected, with 15 million in Turkey and 11 million in Syria. The USGS PAGER service estimated a 36% probability of deaths between 10,000 and 100,000. The Turkish lira and stock markets experienced fluctuations, and the total cost of earthquake damage in Turkey was estimated at $84.1 billion US dollars. The Turkish government released a preliminary report estimating the total damage cost at $103.6 billion. In the aftermath, thousands were trapped under rubble and many people were left homeless. Officials opened hotels and mosques as shelters, and several tens of thousands of people were left homeless. Turkish humanitarian institutions and airlines launched emergency appeals and provided free flights for victims. The Disaster and Emergency Management Authority opened an invitation for citizen volunteers to help with rescue efforts. Emergency services were activated, and over 53,000 Turkish emergency workers were deployed to the affected regions. Poor weather conditions disrupted search and rescue efforts. On 19 February, the Turkish Red Crescent made an appeal for blood donations, and the government said it would pay compensation to those who have lost their homes.

As of 19 February, search and rescue operations continued in Kahramanmaraş and Hatay provinces in Turkey. Charity campaigns were organized, with over $6.1 billion donated by 15 February. The government announced compensation for those who lost their homes and pledged to rebuild destroyed homes within a year. Over 1.9 million people were rehoused in various types of shelters. The Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) declared a ceasefire and called for a focus on recovery efforts. There were incidents of violence and accidents in the affected areas, including a prison riot, clashes between armed groups, and a natural gas explosion. Floods in March killed at least 14 people and displaced many more. The earthquake also raised doubts about whether the 14 May 2023 elections would be held on schedule. The main anti-Erdoğan coalition postponed its meeting for the selection of its consensus presidential candidate. Education and sports were suspended in the affected provinces.

The earthquake in Turkey and Syria led to the postponement of the main anti-Erdoğan coalition's meeting for selecting a consensus presidential candidate. The disaster also raised doubts about whether the 14 May 2023 elections in Turkey would be held on schedule. Education and sports were suspended in the affected provinces, and many universities and schools were used as shelters for those displaced. The earthquake also impacted sports events, with several clubs withdrawing from competitions and international tournaments being canceled. In Syria, the government appealed for international aid, but logistical issues and border closures initially prevented the mobilization of assistance. Hospitals in Syria were overwhelmed with the high number of casualties, and local charities were stretched to their limits. The Syrian Arab Red Crescent called for Western countries to lift sanctions against Syria to aid humanitarian efforts. The United States announced a temporary exemption of sanctions against Syria for 180 days for transactions related to earthquake relief efforts. International humanitarian assistance started entering northwestern Syria on 9 February via Turkey through the Bab al-Hawa Border Crossing.

The earthquake in Turkey and Syria resulted in over 298,000 people losing their homes, with 30,000 of them taking shelter in Aleppo. In rebel-held Jinderis, no international rescue workers had arrived despite requests for help. US sanctions against Syria, including an oil embargo and asset freezes, have been criticized for hindering humanitarian aid during the earthquake recovery effort. However, the US temporarily exempted sanctions for 180 days for transactions related to earthquake relief. International humanitarian assistance, including from the EU, NATO, UN, and ASEAN, has started entering Syria via Turkey. The Turkish government has been criticized for allegedly covering up the scale of the disaster, manipulating the death toll, and having poorly enforced building codes, leading to the collapse of many newly constructed buildings.

The earthquake in Turkey and Syria resulted in massive displacement, with over 298,000 people losing their homes. The US temporarily eased sanctions on Syria for 180 days to facilitate earthquake relief transactions. However, the Turkish government faces criticism for allegedly covering up the disaster's scale, manipulating the death toll, and having poorly enforced building codes. Videos show President Erdoğan praising housing projects that later collapsed, including those granted amnesty certificates. The opposition blames Erdoğan for the disaster's scale and accuses the government of preventing equal aid distribution and favoring AKP-loyal areas. AFAD, the disaster relief agency, is criticized for its slow response, centralization, and inappropriate board management. Military resources were not mobilized until two days after the earthquake, and aid was often held by local governors or the ruling party. A state of emergency was approved in 10 provinces, but the opposition voted against it, claiming it was unnecessary. The Turkish police detained people for "provocative posts" on social media, and arrested 98 for looting. Syrians faced increased discrimination, with allegations of torture and ill-treatment by Turkish security forces. A judicial investigation into building collapses has been initiated, and 612 people are under investigation, with 184 arrested. Journalists have been detained and harassed for their reporting on the earthquake.

The Turkish justice ministry established "Earthquake Crimes Investigation" bureaus to investigate those responsible for building collapses, leading to the arrest of 184 individuals. Journalists have been detained and harassed for their reporting on the earthquake. Building contractors and owners have been arrested for their role in constructing buildings that later collapsed. The majority of collapsed buildings were constructed before 2000, with corruption being a significant issue in the construction sector. Seven days of national mourning were declared in Turkey, Northern Cyprus, Bangladesh, and Kosovo. The Syrian government has been criticized for obstructing aid to opposition-held areas, and the UN has been accused of neglecting the situation in Idlib. The UN has called for the immediate permitting of aid flows into Northwestern Syria, and the US has appealed for the opening of more border crossings for UN aid. Health concerns include the risk of hypothermia and the spread of infection due to damaged sanitation facilities and water shortages. The World Health Organization is collaborating with local authorities to monitor disease rates among the affected.
